quotes:
[]Author: Ionel Roman;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
A strategic location from where you have quick access to many attractions of Rome with cozy clean rooms, friendly and helpful staff and tasteful breakfast. We stayed here for 3 nights and had no problems, our room was cleaned every day, the breakfast was fresh and plentiful (not a lot of different things but enough for every taste) and the staff was very polite (from the reception to the cleaning and the kitchen). We also had an excellent spa day in the hotel with clean dry sauna, jacuzzi and hot steam Turkish bath.

Terrible experience! dirty rooms with cigarette smells! bad breakfast with few options. I definitely don't recommend it. I think they disregard the whole because they are in a good location. Not to mention the time we arrived in the room, with cigarette butts in the toilet and sheets and room stinking of cigarettes. Author: Erin G;
Rating: 3
When: a year ago
Three stars based on convenience and location. I always keep an open mind when traveling abroad, and when staying in bigger cities I expect to pay more for a hotel room. This hotel is definitely on the pricier side. However, I wasn’t in Rome to hang out in a hotel room. It was a place to sleep and served its purpose. Pros: Convenience and location. It’s around the corner from the Trivi Fountain, walking distance to all the touristy spots and easy to find. Complimentary breakfast and nice kitchen staff. They were kind enough to let me borrow a wine opener, and in no hurry to have me return it. Hot tea in the lobby...sometimes. Cons: This wasn’t the cleanest hotel. The rooms and restrooms weren’t the cleanest. Over priced and very loud. You can hear people talking in the hallways and in the other rooms. Looks like they are remodeling. Bottom Line: If this hotel did a better job cleaning the hotel rooms and restrooms I would stay here again.

[]Author: KH Wong;
Rating: 2
When: a year ago
Just a small square with a fountain. Not much really.

Author: Stefano Bucciarelli;
Rating: 4
When: 5 months ago
It characterizes the square Every time I try the history books, I rub my eyes to reread the events of this city. In Piazza Nicosia, suffocated by parked cars, there is the beautiful fountain designed by Giacomo Della Porta. Not just any one, because in Rome there are many works that bear his signature. But this one is not like the others and it was not as we see it today, because it was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, long before Valadier dedicated himself to it heart and soul with his genius. What we see remains: the elevated octagonal basin, the elegant balustrade in cipollino marble and a basin decorated with heraldic emblems. Only three small columns connected by two iron bars protect it from modernity.

Author: Maria Tanasa;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
The fountain in Piazza Nicosia was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, was built in 1572 by Giacomo della Porta for Pope Gregory XIII Boncompagni, whose dragon we note on the basin, to inaugurate the restoration of the Virgin Aqueduct. When Giuseppe Valadier carried out the current restyling of the Piazza del Popolo in 1823, it was demolished to be relocated to Piazza Nicosia in 1950, when renovation work was carried out on the area coordinated by the architect Marcello Piacentini.

Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 3
When: 2 years ago
The Fontana del Trullo was designed by Giacomo Della Porta in 1572. Today it is located in Piazza Nicosia, it was placed here in 1950 (after having been dismantled for several years in the warehouses of the municipality). Very beautiful is the octagonal basin, raised by two steps of the same shape, is the only original part left, the rest are reconstructions. Fortunately it is protected by an area of ​​respect delimited by columns, connected with iron bars. Unfortunately, the vehicles parked around and the small size of the Piazza, do not give the right emphasis to the work.

Church of St. Louis of the French
Rating: 4.8
Popularity:

quotes:
[]Author: Father Kenny Ang;
Rating: 5
When: 6 months ago
This is one of my favorite churches in Rome, since I especially love Caravaggio and his works. Every time I come here, I almost always head directly to the Contarelli chapel just to delight in his three paintings of St. Matthew. My favorite one is the Calling of St. Matthew on the left-side wall of the chapel (which is the darker side of the wall, unfortunately). When I went there yesterday, some ladies already put some euros into the machine so the entire chapel was brightly illuminated. I was a lucky pilgrim and photographer!

Author: Veranika Tsybulskaya;
Rating: 5
When: 7 months ago
Spectacular! Definitely worth to visit not only for a Caravaggio works, but for an ambience itself. Rich and spaced. Were lucky to end up there during the organ mass - truly recommend!

Author: Iman Traveler;
Rating: 5
When: 2 months ago
3 Caravaggio paintings!!! What could you expect more? Short explain: is a Roman Catholic church in Rome, not far from Piazza Navona. The church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary, to St. Denis the Areopagite and St. Louis IX, king of France. The church was designed by Giacomo della Porta and built by Domenico Fontana between 1518 and 1589, and completed through the personal intervention of Catherine de' Medici, who donated to it some property in the area. It is the national church in Rome of France.

Author: Tony Popa;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
The Museo di Roma is a museum in Rome, Italy, part of the network of Roman civic museums. The museum was founded in the Fascist era with the aim of documenting the local history and traditions of the "old Rome" that was rapidly disappearing, but following many donations and acquisitions of works of art is now principally an art museum. The collections initially included 120 water-colours by the nineteenth-century painter Ettore Roesler Franz of Roma sparita, "vanished Rome", later moved to the Museo di Roma in Trastevere.

The presentations are awesome, and it really helps you to understand the history of Rome and the history of the most important locations. Well worth a visit for anyone who is going to Rome without a tour group. The presentations are really great quality too! Can't recommend it enough. The staff are also REALLY helpful and friendly.

It's good, it satiates that craving for pancakes and sausage, but you won't be whistling the national anthem on the way out. The restaurant is cool and definitely had an American vibe, aside from the Tabacchi inside the from door. Generous indoor and outdoor seating, even in this, the age of Corona. Overall, good! You won't be transported back to America, but you will experience a satisfying nostalgia.

Author: Kuala Bound;
Rating: 5
When: 10 months ago
On the Taberna meritoria site Pope Saint Callixtus I founded a church in 220. The actual church basic floor plan date back to 340 while great part of the structure to 1140. Columns came from the Baths of Caracalla. Part of the capitals have been hammered off under Pius IX when some faces were identified as ancient deities.

Author: Ferraro N;
Rating: 5
When: 3 months ago
Our Lady in Trastevere, one of the oldest Basilicas in Rome. It hosts beautiful mosaics from the 13th century. The church has a romanesque campanile and it is erected in an large square named after the Basilica, Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere. The interiors of the church feature two main naves separated by granite columns.

Author: JUZER KAPADIA;
Rating: 5
When: a month ago
Trastevere, which literally translates as the area “across the Tiber,” is one of the city’s most attractive quarters: a maze of narrow, cobbled alleys. Once home to the city’s poor, the neighborhood has witnessed a proliferation of fashionable clubs, restaurants, and boutiques. At the heart of this charming quarter, overlooking an attractive traffic-free square, stands the Basilica of Santa Maria – probably the first official place of Christian worship in Rome. It was founded by Pope Callixtus I in the 3rd century, when Christianity was still a minority cult. According to legend, the church was built on the site where a fountain of oil had sprung up miraculously on the day that Christ was born. The basilica became the focus of devotion to the Virgin Mary and today is famous for its splendid mosaics. Both the Madonna and Christ are among the figures depicted in the facade mosaics (c. 12th century), while in the apse is a stylized 12th-century mosaic portraying the Coronation of the Virgin. Below it are a series of realistic mosaic scenes from the life of Mary by the 13th-century Roman artist Pietro Cavallini. The oldest image of the Virgin is a 7th-century icon, which depicts her as a Byzantine empress flanked by a guard of angels. Another image of the Virgin and Child can be seen near the top of the campanile

[]Author: Carlo Carlevale;
Rating: 4
When: a month ago
It is one of the oldest scientific institutions in Europe. It was founded in Rome in 1603 by Federico Cesi, Francesco Stelluti, Anastasio De Filiis and Johannes van Heeck, in order to establish a meeting place for the development of the sciences. Its name refers to the sharpness that must have the sight of those who dedicate themselves to the sciences, to the future and to human progress, a property that characterizes the lynx, in relation to sight. The Accademia dei Lincei has undergone many changes over time. After a first period of great prestige, due to the work of Cesi and the other founders and to the presence of partners such as Galileo Galilei and Giovanni Battista Della Porta, after Cesi's death in 1630, the Academy reduced its activities to almost to disappear. Only in 1847 there was a real resumption of its activities by Pope Pius IX who re-founded it in the Pontifical Academy of the Nuovi Lincei, which still exists today. Subsequently from 1936 with the name of Pontifical Academy of Sciences. Since 1986 the Accademia dei Lincei has been governed by a Statute which provides for it to be composed of 540 academics, divided according to three qualifications. Therefore 180 are the "national" ordinary members, 180 the "foreign" ordinary members and 180 are the "corresponding" members. All members are then divided into two classes: the first is that of Physical Sciences, while the second is that of Moral Sciences. Since 2001 the Physical Sciences Class is divided into 5 categories, while the Moral Sciences Class is divided into 7 categories. The academy is located in the Villa Farnesina, in Rome; it was built between 1506 and 1512 by the young Peruzzi for the very wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi, a great patron and prominent figure in early 16th century Rome, who had amassed a large fortune from the proceeds of the sale of the Tolfa alum and who enjoyed the protection of Pope Julius II first, and then Leo X. The Farnesina, which at the time was simply called Villa Chigi, was the first suburban noble villa in Rome and had a great prominence from the beginning, soon being cited and imitated. The architectural interventions, although they could be considered completed in 1512, continued for other works until 1520. With the death of Chigi, in 1520, the villa declined and was depleted of furnishings and works of art. In 1580 it was purchased by Cardinal Alessandro Farnese and thus had its current name. An unrealized project dates back to this period to connect Palazzo Farnese with the Farnesina with a covered passage. In 1714 it became the property of the Bourbons of Naples and in 1864 the ambassador Bermudez de Castro settled there, who, two years later, promoted a series of heavy restorations. In 1884 the opening of the Lungotevere involved the destruction of a part of the gardens and of the loggia on the river, which perhaps had been designed by Raphael. As already mentioned, it has belonged to the Italian State since 1927, which had it restored in 1929 -1942 to be assigned to the Academy of Italy and on several occasions in 1969-1983. Today it is used by the Accademia dei Lincei as a representative office and houses, on the first floor, the national print cabinet.

Author: JUZER KAPADIA;
Rating: 5
When: a month ago
The wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi commissioned this villa in 1508 for his lavish banquets and for sojourns with the courtesan Imperia, who allegedly inspired one of the Three Graces painted by Raphael in the Loggia of Cupid and Psyche. Designed by the Sienese architect Baldassare Peruzzi, the harmonious Farnesina, with a central block and projecting wings, is one of the first true Renaissance villas. Peruzzi decorated some of the interiors himself, such as the Sala della Prospettiva upstairs, in which illusionistic frescoes create the impression of looking out over Rome through a marble colonnade. The painted vault of the Sala di Galatea shows the position of the stars at the time of Chigi’s birth. After his death, the banking business collapsed, and in 1577 the villa was sold to the Farnese family.

[]Author: Ghazzal Mehdi;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
Surely a five star place. Perhaps the most iconic in Rome? To be honest, Rome has so many iconic places that I lost the count... Anyway, near to. Vetican, great bridges.. Simply outstanding...

Author: Marcos Chavarria;
Rating: 4
When: a month ago
Greater sight from the outside, I hope the pictures make sense of the very nice place this is. The architecture is different from other landmarks as it was intended for a different purpose in the religious history. Prepare to walk a lot. I would recommend the walking tour if possible.

Author: Marcel van Poeijer;
Rating: 4
When: 3 months ago
This huge Castle is definitely worth a visit. Even though I did not go in (entrance fee = 15EU), I still loved the outside area and the little park next to it. When you go inside, it is recommended to go before sunrise, as the sunrise view on top of the terrace should be lovely.

Author: Ken Saberi;
Rating: 4
When: 7 months ago
Great place to visit with spectacular views all around Rome. Interesting artefacts and some Papal history to see. Some of the rooms are stunning. There are a lot of stairs so people with mobility issues may struggle although there is a lift to the second level which can be used on request. This does mean that you will lose out on the top terrace which provides the best views. All the staff were extremely helpful and kind.

Author: Rich;
Rating: 3
When: 7 months ago
A fine visit. The best thing about this castle is the view you get once you're on the top floor.

Amazing food, great wine. This is Rome. Waitress recommended all of our food and I couldn’t be happier!

Author: George Kolios;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
A warm place for every hour of the day in the center of Rome. Tasty food and a nice atmospheric bar. The waiters were very friendly and the service perfect. We will be back again…

Author: Jeremy Holifield;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
exceptional cheese flavors and cooked perfectly. The waiter recommended two pizzas, but one sufficed. Highly recommend.

Author: Alfonso Irnan;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
Great ambience for a few drinks or even for a dinner. The meals are good in quality, the selection of drinks is also excellent, with some cocktails to delight. Very advisable.

Author: Benedict Hince;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
A really comfortable and warm place with good coffee. The comfy chairs really won me over, as did the interior design. I can't vouch for the food as I did not try anything. But I'd be happy to recommend this place as a good meeting point to grab a coffee.

[]Author: Ionel Roman;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
A strategic location from where you have quick access to many attractions of Rome with cozy clean rooms, friendly and helpful staff and tasteful breakfast. We stayed here for 3 nights and had no problems, our room was cleaned every day, the breakfast was fresh and plentiful (not a lot of different things but enough for every taste) and the staff was very polite (from the reception to the cleaning and the kitchen). We also had an excellent spa day in the hotel with clean dry sauna, jacuzzi and hot steam Turkish bath.

Author: massimo mancusi;

Author: Mel Levi;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
We stayed 5 nights from Nov 9-14th. Very pleased with the hotel. GREAT location. Nice rooms and breakfast. Staff is wonderful and very helpful. First night we were put in a small room as hotel was at 100% occupancy. They moved us to a very nice room for nights 2-5. Would certainly stay there again and recommend.

Author: Giovanna Gravina;
Rating: 1
When: a year ago
Terrible experience! dirty rooms with cigarette smells! bad breakfast with few options. I definitely don't recommend it. I think they disregard the whole because they are in a good location. Not to mention the time we arrived in the room, with cigarette butts in the toilet and sheets and room stinking of cigarettes. We just didn't change hotels because it was time to go back to our country. Not sure how it fits into a 3 star hotel.

Author: Erin G;
Rating: 3
When: a year ago
Three stars based on convenience and location. I always keep an open mind when traveling abroad, and when staying in bigger cities I expect to pay more for a hotel room. This hotel is definitely on the pricier side. However, I wasn’t in Rome to hang out in a hotel room. It was a place to sleep and served its purpose. Pros: Convenience and location. It’s around the corner from the Trivi Fountain, walking distance to all the touristy spots and easy to find. Complimentary breakfast and nice kitchen staff. They were kind enough to let me borrow a wine opener, and in no hurry to have me return it. Hot tea in the lobby...sometimes. Cons: This wasn’t the cleanest hotel. The rooms and restrooms weren’t the cleanest. Over priced and very loud. You can hear people talking in the hallways and in the other rooms. Looks like they are remodeling. Bottom Line: If this hotel did a better job cleaning the hotel rooms and restrooms I would stay here again.
